meta.title: World 2: Operators & Expressions - Lessons
meta.intro: In this world, you’ll learn how Python performs math, compares values, and uses logic to make decisions.

lessons.title: Arithmetic Operators
lessons.html:
Python can do basic math easily using arithmetic operators: +, -, *, /, %, and **.

print(5 + 3)   # 8 (addition)
print(7 - 2)   # 5 (subtraction)
print(4 * 2)   # 8 (multiplication)
print(9 / 2)   # 4.5 (division)
print(9 % 2)   # 1 (remainder)
print(2 ** 3)  # 8 (power)

Analogy: Think of these like buttons on a calculator. Python is your calculator brain!

lessons.title: Comparison Operators
lessons.html:
Comparison operators check how values relate: == (equal), != (not equal), > (greater), < (less), >=, <=.

x = 5
y = 8
print(x == y)  # False
print(x < y)   # True
print(x != y)  # True

Analogy: It’s like asking questions: "Is x equal to y?" Python answers True or False.

lessons.title: Logical Operators
lessons.html:
Logical operators combine conditions: and, or, not.

age = 18
print(age >= 10 and age < 20)  # True
print(age < 10 or age > 20)   # False
print(not(age == 18))         # False

Analogy: Imagine traffic lights: and is like needing both green lights, or is okay if any is green, not flips the result.

lessons.title: Operator Precedence
lessons.html:
Python follows the order of operations (PEMDAS: Parentheses, Exponents, Multiplication/Division, Addition/Subtraction).

print(2 + 3 * 4)    # 14
print((2 + 3) * 4)  # 20

Analogy: Like math class: multiplication before addition, unless you use brackets.
